caption_original: Look how far this Bluefin tuna travelled last winter! Our fishery officers and biologists worked together to recover a tag off Shippagan, New Brunswick, that had been attached to a Bluefin tuna for over a year. It showed the tuna was originally tagged on October 17, 2016 off of Port Mouton, Nova Scotia. The tuna stayed in Canadian waters until December and then travelled 3,000 km to the southwest of the Azores before making its way back to Nova Scotia in April. More info on how tagging helps us better understand the species: http://ow.ly/4FV830gHA0j

caption_original: Oh, the things you can see when you look below the surface! As part of our annual summer survey aboard the Canadian Coast Guard CCGS Alfred Needler, our scientists explored the deep waters of the Scotian Shelf off the coast of Nova Scotia. Although sampling marine life below the surface requires a lot of patience, sometimes up to an hour, when the 3,000 metre-long trawl cables reach the bottom, the unusual species we see are well worth the wait. More info on multi-species bottom trawl surveys here: http://ow.ly/Eq5P30grkPh

caption_original: Northern Snakehead is an invasive species that has not yet been found in any of Canada‚Äôs aquatic ecosystems, but we want to be on the lookout! Most snakehead species are native to warmer regions, but the Northern Snakehead occurs naturally in colder waters. Northern Snakehead can eat practically any small animal or fish they encounter. They can travel across land and live out of water for at least three days and reproduce quickly. If they find a way into natural freshwater ecosystems, they have the potential to cause serious damage to recreational and commercial fisheries. Report sightings: http://ow.ly/J8pb30gvleY

caption_original: Canada's first marine biological research station began operations in St. Andrews, New Brunswick in 1899. Built aboard a floating raft, the station was very small and resembled a Pullman railway car. After moving around Canada for several years, the Biological Board of Canada decided that a permanent biological station was needed on the Atlantic coast. St. Andrews was chosen because of the diverse biological and physical environment in Passamaquoddy Bay and the Bay of Fundy and its proximity to important commercial fisheries for herring, groundfish and invertebrate species. Learn more about what is now the St. Andrews Biological Station http://ow.ly/GG8630gzBd0

caption_original:
For the past two years, our team of Quebec biologists has been collecting data on artificial reefs developed for American lobster in the Magdalen Islands and the Gasp√© Peninsula. These 10m by 20m reefs are composed mainly of rocks of different sizes. They serve to offset the serious harm caused by marine environment projects by providing shelter and food for lobsters of all sizes. They become true nurseries for these crustaceans and are also, according to what the dives on the sites have shown, colonized by a wide variety of organisms.

Biologists now better understand the benefits of these developments to the surrounding environment and can make recommendations to developers to increase the stability of development over the longer term. Learn more about the Fisheries Protection Program: http://ow.ly/zFin30gNgIg

Biologists now better understand the benefits of these developments to the surrounding environment and can make recommendations to developers to increase the stability of development over the longer term. Learn more about the Fisheries Protection Program:

caption_original: Help protect our oceans! We work hard to keep Canada‚Äôs waters and coasts safe and clean through programs and initiatives like the Oceans Protection Plan and Coastal Restoration Fund. But we can‚Äôt do it alone. To encourage the public to get involved, we visit communities with educational materials and take part in school visits and beach clean-ups. Unfortunately, the waters around many Canadian harbours aren‚Äôt as clean as they could be. Recently, our researchers from Newfoundland and Labrador, Corey Morris & Dan Porter, presented results from a survey of 18 harbours over 10 years. During scientific dives, they unexpectedly found, and videotaped, lots of garbage ‚Äì everything from carpet, rubber gloves, rubber boots to appliances like BBQs, stove, even a washer with laundry still inside. Everyone has a role in protecting the ocean and the creatures that live there. Reduce the garbage going into the ocean by recycling, reusing and refusing plastic where you can.
caption_cleaned: Help protect our oceans! Unfortunately, the waters around many Canadian harbours aren‚Äôt as clean as they could be. Recently, our researchers from Newfoundland and Labrador, Corey Morris & Dan Porter, presented results from a survey of harbours over years. During scientific dives, they uneectedly found, and videotaped, lots of garbage ‚Äì everything from carpet, rubber gloves, rubber boots to appliances like BBQs, stove, even a washer with laundry still inside. Everyone has a role in protecting the ocean and the creatures that live there. Reduce the garbage going into the ocean by recycling, reusing and refusing plastic where you can.

caption_original: We are taking concrete action to protect the endangered North Atlantic Right Whale for future generations. We will be working with partners on a comprehensive approach which includes specific proposals like seasonal speed restrictions to avoid collisions, adjusting fishing gear and testing new gear to reduce the risk of whale entanglements, and working to reduce lost fishing gear in our waters. These strategies were discussed at a roundtable with experts, scientists, Indigenous peoples and representatives from fishing organizations and marine transportation industries in Moncton, New Brunswick yesterday. In addition to the speed restrictions and increased surveillance implemented this past summer, these actions will help us better protect this iconic species. https://t.co/oUilvkXaHj
caption_cleaned: We are taking concrete action to protect the endangered North Atlantic Right Whale for future generations. We will be working with partners on a comprehensive approach which includes specific proposals like seasonal speed restrictions to avoid collisions, adjusting fishing gear and testing new gear to reduce the risk of whale entanglements, and working to reduce lost fishing gear in our waters. These strategies were discussed at a roundtable with eerts, scientists, Indigenous peoples and representatives from fishing organizations and marine transportation industries in Moncton, New Brunswick yesterday. In addition to the speed restrictions and increased surveillance implemented this past summer, these actions will help us better protect this iconic species.

caption_original: We‚Äôre proud to announce the Mi‚Äôkmaq Alsumk Mowimsikik Koqoey Association (Miawpukek Mi'kamawey Mawi'omi) will receive $404,100 over two years from the Coastal Restoration Fund to help restore the marine ecosystem in Newfoundland and Labrador. This investment will help remediate Claybank, located along the shoreline of the McDonalds Recreation area in the Miawpukek Reserve. It has been severely affected by extreme weather conditions, disturbing Atlantic salmon migration. To learn more about this project, please visit: http://ow.ly/eKjI30gIMtZ

caption_original:
Our scientist, Nathalie Simard, studies aquatic invasive species to protect our waters and the ecosystems, economies, and communities that depend on them. Every year, this biologist from the Maurice Lamontagne Institute in Mont-Joli, Quebec and her colleagues visit various ports and marinas. They try to detect new invasive species as soon as they arrive and follow the evolution of those already there.
Learn more about aquatic invasive species: http://ow.ly/x76O30gzyeO

caption_original: Fishery officers in Newfoundland and Labrador monitor the recreational groundfish fishery every year as part of regular fishery patrols. This year, we were pleased to find that once again most participants are keeping conservation in mind and respecting the rules. Of over 1,000 boat inspections, only 44 violations were detected. Two areas where more conservation-minded behaviour is needed are in throwing back fish in hopes of a better catch and going over the daily bag limit.

Two areas where more conservation-minded behaviour is needed are in throwing back fish in hopes of a better catch and going over the daily bag limit.

caption_original: Our Atlantic salmon assessment team completed a fall swim through on the Big Salmon River in New Brunswick where Atlantic salmon spawns. This swim through helps to assess the status of the endangered Inner Bay of Fundy Atlantic salmon population. Given that the section of the river they assess is fairly large, help from our partners is needed. Thanks to the Fort Folly First Nation, the Houlton Band of Maliseet Indians and the Mi‚Äôkmaq Conservation Group who helped us complete this activity. http://ow.ly/qcvn30gobyz

caption_original: Earlier this month, St. Andrew‚Äôs Biological Station biologists conducted an exploratory acoustic survey of Pollock off Southwest Nova Scotia. Pollock populations are difficult to assess using bottom-trawl surveys because they sometimes live off of the ocean bottom. This work is part of a collaborative agreement between the Ground fish Enterprise Allocation Council and Fisheries and Oceans Canada to better understand Pollock populations.

caption_original: Did you know that you can protect sea turtles by using less plastic? Sea turtles may mistake plastic for food or get tangled up in various kinds of plastic, such as six-pack rings from pop cans or packing straps. caption_original: Our Conservation and Protection division adapts its monitoring and enforcement activities to respond to changes in fishing activity or management measures. This year, due to low salmon returns for the island of Newfoundland, the Atlantic salmon fishery changed mid-season to catch and release for the area. Our officers and guardians patrolled and monitored both open and closed rivers during the regular season and after the change to no-retention angling. We inspected 3,901 anglers and found 141 violations, a decrease compared to previous years with no apparent increase in illegal activities during the no-retention portion of the season. Please continue to report all suspicious fishing activities to your local DFO office: http://ow.ly/OJFo30gzAdg or Crime Stoppers.

We inspected ,901 anglers and found violations, a decrease compared to previous years with no apparent increase in illegal activities during the no-retention portion of the season. Please continue to report all suspicious fishing activities to your local DFO office: or Crime Stoppers.

caption_original: A shell thief! That's how you could describe the hermit crab. A small crab with no shell, it protects itself by hiding in empty shells it finds along the way. It switches to larger shells each time it grows. What a savvy sustainability expert!
caption_cleaned: A shell thief! That's how you could describe the hermit crab. A small crab with no shell, it protects itself by hiding in empty shells it finds along the way. It switches to larger shells each time it grows. What a savvy sustainability eert!

caption_original:
The Quagga Mussel is an Aquatic Invasive Species closely related to the invasive Zebra Mussel. The Quagga mussel is found in the southern Great Lakes (lakes Ontario, Michigan, Huron and Erie). Although they have already invaded parts of Ontario, other provinces, like Alberta, Manitoba, and Saskatchewan are working to prevent them from establishing there. If you think you‚Äôve seen or caught a Quagga Mussel:
* Do not release it into the water.
* Collect it and keep it frozen. If you can‚Äôt do that, destroy it.
* Note the location (with GPS coordinates if possible) as well as the observation date.
* Contact Fisheries and Oceans Canada
Click here for more information about this Aquatic Invasive Species: http://ow.ly/e3fV30goji4

Although they have already invaded parts of Ontario, other provinces, like Alberta, Manitoba, and Saskatchewan are working to prevent them from establishing there. If you think you‚Äôve seen or caught a Quagga Mussel: * Do not release it into the water. * Collect it and keep it frozen. If you can‚Äôt do that, destroy it. * Note the location (with GPS coordinates if possible) as well as the observation date. * Contact Fisheries and Oceans Canada Click here for more information about this Aquatic Invasive Species:
